thread.title: McHugh pitches Astros to 5-2 win over Royals to open ALDS
thread.title_full: McHugh pitches Astros to 5-2 win over Royals to open ALDS

title: McHugh pitches Astros to 5-2 win over Royals to open ALDS
text:
McHugh pitches Astros to 5-2 win over Royals to open ALDS - Western Mass News - WGGB/WSHM Member Center: In the Know McHugh pitches Astros to 5-2 win over Royals to open ALDS (AP Photo/Orlin Wagner). Houston Astros' George Springer celebrates after his solo home run during the fifth inning in Game 1 of baseball's American League Division Series against the Kansas City Royals, Thursday, Oct. 8, 2015, in Kansas City, Mo. (AP Photo/Charlie Riedel). Kansas City Royals' Kendrys Morales watches his solo home run during the fourth inning in Game 1 of baseball's American League Division Series against the Houston Astros, Thursday, Oct. 8, 2015, in Kansas City, Mo. (AP Photo/Charlie Riedel). Houston Astros' Jose Altuve, right, is tagged out by Kansas City Royals second baseman Ben Zobrist, left, while trying to steal second base during the fifth inning in Game 1 of baseball's American League Division Series, Thur... (AP Photo/Orlin Wagner). Kansas City Royals' Ben Zobrist, right, steals second base as Houston Astros second baseman Jose Altuve, left, leaps for the throw during the first inning in Game 1 of baseball's American League Division Series, Thursday, Oct. ... (AP Photo/Orlin Wagner). Jets fly over Kauffman Stadium before Game 1 of baseball's American League Division Series between the Kansas City Royals and the Houston Astros, Thursday, Oct. 8, 2015, in Kansas City, Mo. By DAVE SKRETTAAP Sports Writer 
KANSAS CITY, Mo. (AP) - The Houston Astros beat the Kansas City Royals at their own game Thursday night, relying on sharp pitching from Collin McHugh and stingy defense behind him for a 5-2 victory in the opener of their AL Division Series. 
McHugh (1-0) allowed four hits, including a pair of solo homers by Kendrys Morales, while pitching around a 49-minute rain delay. The right-hander lasted six innings before turning the game over to his bullpen, which scattered just three runners over the final three frames. 
Tony Sipp, Will Harris and Oliver Perez got the game to Luke Gregerson, part of Oakland's wild-card collapse in Kansas City last year. He handled the ninth to earn the save. 
George Springer and Colby Rasmus went deep for the homer-happy Astros, but they also scored via the same sort of small ball the Royals used in reaching the World Series last season.
